did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Andrew Dickson White architectural photograph collection, [ca. 1865-1950]
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Includes approximately 13,000 photographs of buildings, sculpture and decorative arts in the United States, Europe and the Middle East. Collection consists of nineteenth- and early twentieth-century photographs: 9,000 individual, mounted images and about 150 albums containing approximately 4,000 images. Other sub-collections include nineteenth-century American domestic architecture, 1893 Chicago Columbian Exposition, plans and drawings by fellows of the American Academy in Rome (200 items, ca. 1930-1940); Clifton Beckwith Brown memorial albums (118 albums containing about 2,600 images); photographs of drawings of the U. S. Capitol Building and U. S. Treasury Buildings by Alfred B. Mullett, supervising architect of the U.S. Treasury; three albums of views of the Middle East by Félix Bonfils; photogravures of the Louvre Museum by Edouard-Denis Baldus; and Metropolitan Museum period rooms. Photographic processes include albumen prints, carbon prints, cyanotypes, photogravures, and gelatin silver prints.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Educator, diplomat, president of Cornell University.

His tenure as University president (1866-85) was interrupted by an official visit to Santo Domingo and a term as U.S. Minister to Berlin. He later served as Minister to Russia and then Ambassador to Germany. After the death of his first wife, Mary Amanda Outwater, White married Helen Magill. He died in 1918.
Andrew D. White taught at the University of Michigan, then served in the New York State Senate (1864-67). He next became Cornell's first president.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Includes approximately 13,000 photographs of buildings, sculpture and decorative arts in the United States, Europe and the Middle East. Collection consists of nineteenth- and early twentieth-century photographs: 9,000 individual, mounted images and about 150 albums containing approximately 4,000 images. Other sub-collections include nineteenth-century American domestic architecture, 1893 Chicago Columbian Exposition, plans and drawings by fellows of the American Academy in Rome (200 items, ca. 1930-1940); Clifton Beckwith Brown memorial albums (118 albums containing about 2,600 images); photographs of drawings of the U. S. Capitol Building and U. S. Treasury Buildings by Alfred B. Mullett, supervising architect of the U.S. Treasury; three albums of views of the Middle East by Félix Bonfils; photogravures of the Louvre Museum by Edouard-Denis Baldus; and Metropolitan Museum period rooms. Photographic processes include albumen prints, carbon prints, cyanotypes, photogravures, and gelatin silver prints.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Andrew Dickson White Architectural Photograph Collection, #15-5-3090. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

odd.head: NOTES
odd.p: See also: Andrew D. White Architectural Photographs digital collection, which consists of digitized images from this collection.
